Bodhisattvas, life after life, have cherished precious and rare treasures that they have given to others. They have always given good eyes and kind thoughts as gifts. For this reason, the Buddha has attained wisdom and knows the scriptures and teachings.

The Bodhisattva, lifetime after lifetime, served his teachers and parents. If he saw them sleeping, he did not disturb them frequently. If he wanted to wake them, he would play music or recite sutras with beautiful words to wake them up. For this reason, when the Buddha was in silence, the devas, Brahma, and Indra held music and incense to wake him up.

The Bodhisattva, lifetime after lifetime, built monasteries for the Buddha and arranged fine bedding and furnishings. For this reason, mosquitoes, gadflies, bees, snakes, fleas, lice, and their ilk did not dare approach the Buddha's body.

The Bodhisattva, lifetime after lifetime, during the cold winter months, made fine and beautiful clothes for the Buddha and the Bodhisattvas. For this reason, when a storm arose in front of the Buddha, it was neither cold nor hot, and the hairs on his clothes did not move.

The Bodhisattva, life after life, had wonderful and delicious food and drink, and never ate alone. If his teacher, parents, or others had food and drink, he would not eat without sharing it with them. For this reason, although the Buddha set aside his majestic power and, although he had nothing to eat, the Buddha was neither hungry nor thirsty, and his body did not become emaciated.
